I’ve spent some time with this game and honestly, it surprised me in a way I didn’t fully expect. I don’t want to sound dramatic, but there’s something oddly satisfying about how everything fits together — not in some perfect, polished “advertisement” way, but more like a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and just… goes for it.

The first thing I noticed is the atmosphere. Every part of the game — the visuals, the sound, the pacing — kind of blends into this feeling that you’re actually inside its world, even if you’re just casually playing. I know that sounds a bit cliché, but it’s true. Sometimes it’s chaotic, sometimes slow, sometimes you’re just wandering around thinking “ok, what now?” but that’s honestly part of the charm. The game doesn’t try to rush you unless it actually needs to.

Gameplay-wise, it has this mix of familiar elements and small twists that keep things from feeling stale. Nothing groundbreaking, maybe, but it all works together in a way that feels natural. There were moments when I thought “yeah, I’ve seen this in other games,” but then the game throws in tiny details or unexpected interactions that make it stand out just enough. It’s the kind of thing you only notice after a few hours, when you start connecting the dots.

Performance has been mostly fine. A little rough spot here and there, but honestly, show me a game these days that doesn’t have something weird happening once in a while. Nothing game-breaking on my end, at least. You can clearly tell the developers put effort into this, even if a few edges are still a bit sharp. Again — part of the charm.

What I really appreciate is that the game gives you space to play the way you want. Some people will rush through every objective, others will take their time exploring or messing around, and both approaches actually feel valid. I like games that don’t punish you for not following some “correct” path.

Overall, I’d say this is one of those titles that grows on you the longer you play. It doesn’t try too hard to impress in the first five minutes — instead it slowly builds its identity, layer by layer, until you suddenly realize you’ve been playing way longer than you planned. If you’re looking for something that balances comfort with challenge, familiar mechanics with fresh touches, and a world that’s just fun to be in, then I genuinely think this one is worth giving a shot.

Would I recommend it?
Yeah, I would — maybe not to everyone, because no game is for everyone, but definitely to anyone who likes getting lost in a game for a bit and discovering things at their own pace.

A colorful and strategic hero shooter often compared to Overwatch, but Paladins has its own unique charm and much deeper customization. The core of the game is the "Cards" system, which lets you tailor each champion's abilities to your playstyle, making every match feel different.

The champions are diverse, vibrant, and full of personality. Game modes are fun, and the core objective-based gameplay is solid. The game can be a bit buggy at times, and the balance isn't always perfect. However, it's a free-to-play title with a surprisingly fair model.

Paladins is chaotic, colorful, and gloriously unbalanced… and that’s exactly why it’s impossible to quit.

After sinking over 450 hours into Paladins, I can confidently say this is one of the most enjoyable hero shooters you can get—especially for free.

Is Paladins perfect? No. The matchmaking can be hit-or-miss, and balance patches sometimes feel like they were decided by throwing darts at a board. But when the gameplay clicks it’s genuinely some of the most fun I’ve had in a shooter.

For anyone wondering if Paladins is worth trying or returning to:
Yes. Absolutely.

It’s chaotic, stylish, surprisingly strategic, and still manages to be addictive after hundreds of hours. If you’re willing to embrace its quirks, you’ll find a game with a ton of depth and replayability.

450 hours later, and I’m still not done.

All in all, I liked the gameplay. But disliked the "free-to-play" monetization. Every new character (non-free) they introduced was always OP, until they introduced a new character (again OP) and "re-balanced" the earlier one. You could usually pay for them with an exorbitant amount of in-game currency, or a fairly small sum of real-life money. So "free-to-play" became "pay-to-win".

I especially liked the character skill/attribute customization options, where you could build your character to your own play-style. There might not be overly many players online, anymore, but I would recommend trying this.

A 5v5 team-based shooter like Paladins looked very promising on paper. It had a good variety of maps, a large roster of unique champions with different abilities, and even a shop system where you could buy extra perks to improve your stats. The gameplay felt fast and dynamic - fights were happening all the time, yet it never felt overwhelming or chaotic.

The balance and anti-cheat existed, though not always in their best shape. Still, for a while, the game managed to stay alive, build its own community, and even have an esports scene. But as time went on, it stopped evolving. Players began complaining that the only updates were new skins, while major improvements were nowhere to be seen. The game had squeezed out everything it could from its audience - and decline followed.

It's not a bad game by any means, but today it's simply not worth your attention anymore.

Where to start ...

Paladins isn't like any other game. People claim it's a hero shooter clone, that it doesn't deserve players since it's a "copy." I used to think that was furthest from the truth. 

This game has the best mechanics and (dare I say) hero design out of any team shooter. Had the devs had a fraction of the budget that the OW (1) devs spent on wh*res and SAing their employees, this game would have had its spot on the top of the mountain.

Then, Marvel Rivals came along. When you got two big dogs duking it out, it's hard to claim a spot at the table. Paladins got squeezed out by competition with deeper pockets, but not competition with deeper hearts. Had the community picked it up, had streamers not sh*t on it live, maybe it would have had a chance. In another universe, I like to think that this game had its time to shine. But the truth is, now, it is unplayable. Be it hackers, long queue times, bugs, or whatever else, every single fan is being slowly kicked out of the game.

I used to play Paladins on Xbox for hours everyday. Well over 200 hours on record. Sometimes I think a portion of my life has been wasted, but then I think back to all the fun times I had.

Hi-Rez, if you're out there, make Paladins 2 a thing. It might be a lot of work, but there is a dedicated fanbase here that is ready and willing to kick their OW and Marvel Rivals overlords to the curb.

A 5v5 team-based shooter like Paladins looked very promising on paper. It had a good variety of maps, a large roster of unique champions with different abilities, and even a shop system where you could buy extra perks to improve your stats. The gameplay felt fast and dynamic - fights were happening all the time, yet it never felt overwhelming or chaotic.

The balance and anti-cheat existed, though not always in their best shape. Still, for a while, the game managed to stay alive, build its own community, and even have an esports scene. But as time went on, it stopped evolving. Players began complaining that the only updates were new skins, while major improvements were nowhere to be seen. The game had squeezed out everything it could from its audience - and decline followed.

It's not a bad game by any means, but today it's simply not worth your attention anymore.

Where to start ...

Paladins isn't like any other game. People claim it's a hero shooter clone, that it doesn't deserve players since it's a "copy." I used to think that was furthest from the truth. 

This game has the best mechanics and (dare I say) hero design out of any team shooter. Had the devs had a fraction of the budget that the OW (1) devs spent on wh*res and SAing their employees, this game would have had its spot on the top of the mountain.

Then, Marvel Rivals came along. When you got two big dogs duking it out, it's hard to claim a spot at the table. Paladins got squeezed out by competition with deeper pockets, but not competition with deeper hearts. Had the community picked it up, had streamers not sh*t on it live, maybe it would have had a chance. In another universe, I like to think that this game had its time to shine. But the truth is, now, it is unplayable. Be it hackers, long queue times, bugs, or whatever else, every single fan is being slowly kicked out of the game.

I used to play Paladins on Xbox for hours everyday. Well over 200 hours on record. Sometimes I think a portion of my life has been wasted, but then I think back to all the fun times I had.

Hi-Rez, if you're out there, make Paladins 2 a thing. It might be a lot of work, but there is a dedicated fanbase here that is ready and willing to kick their OW and Marvel Rivals overlords to the curb.
